awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Alternative defensive mechanisms of autotrophs from harmful reactive oxygen species
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyanobacteria (also known as blue-green algae) are capable of thriving in a variety of environments. Ecological disturbances often favor growth of cyanobacteria because of their capability to adapt to rapid changes in the environment. Sometimes changes in environmental conditions can result in dense populations of cyanobacteria, (algal bloom) and they may also produce high concentrations of toxins (cyanotoxins) that kill fish and are a hazard to humans. The goal of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to test whether cyanotoxins have an important alternative biochemical and ecological function, namely, to protect the cyanobacteria by removing hydrogen peroxide. If this proves to be true, it would transform our understanding of the structure and function of freshwater lakes.  The results from this EAGER project may also lead to more effective and economical management of harmful cyanobacerial blooms. Cyanotoxins released during harmful algal blooms can pose health risks, and require millions of dollars to decontaminate freshwater supplies. The project will also include research training opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, with efforts to broaden participation in science.

One of the most important environmental gradients is formed by oxygen, and its availability is fundamental to the distribution patterns of life. Cyanobacteria were the first lineage to establish oxygen-producing photosynthesis. Cyanobacterial photosynthesis captures solar energy, but it comes at the risk of producing reactive oxygen species such as hydrogen peroxide. The development of a cellular process capable of handling intracellular reactive oxygen molecules was key to the evolution of cyanobacterial photosynthesis. This EAGER project will test an intriguing hypothesis about why cyanobacteria produce cyanotoxins, that they function to sequester hydrogen peroxide, or otherwise convert it to a non-reactive form. In this project, toxic and non-toxic cyanobacterial strains will be compared with respect to hydrogen peroxide production. A new hydrogen peroxide microsensor will be used to examine the microscale distribution of hydrogen peroxide in thin surface lake water to determine whether (consistent with the hypothesis) it is inversely proportional with the abundance of toxin-producing cyanobacteria. Finally, studies will determine whether the ability to isolate and grow novel cyanobacteria in culture can be improved by adding alpha-keto acids to scavenge any hydrogen peroxide produced by cells.

por.por_cntn:
Planet Earth provides a vast variety of habitats for microorganisms. One of the most important environmental gradients is formed by oxygen, and its availability strictly sets the distribution patterns of life. For many organisms, oxygen is an essential electron acceptor. Among the many prokaryotes, cyanobacteria became the first lineage to establish oxygen-producing photosynthesis which has a great energetic advantage at the risk of handling reactive oxygen species (ROS). The development of a cellular process capable of handling intracellular oxygen was a key to the survival of cyanobacteria in nature.

 

A long-standing debate in the scientific community surrounds the biochemical roles of toxin production by cyanobacteria. New to this discussion and potentially transformative to the field is the idea that cyanotoxins are produced as ROS scavengers. The idea arose from the use of hydrogen peroxide to control harmful cyanobacterial blooms. In this treatment, cyanotoxins are detoxified by hydrogen peroxide. A similar mechanism is proposed here, where cyanotoxins may act as an intercellular oxygen handling system in which they scavenge hydrogen peroxide and destroy ROS in the cyanobacterial cells. Through this potentially transformative research, this mechanism could resolve a long-standing debate for the regulation and function of cyanotoxins.

 

Cyanobacteria are capable of thriving in a variety of environments. Recent human- induced environmental changes such as climate and eutrophication, may favor cyanobacteria because of their capability to adapt to rapid environmental changes, preference for warm temperature, and the adaptation to harsh environments. Understanding the “trigger” of cyanotoxin production is essential for the effective management of toxic cyanobacterial blooms. Moreover, understanding of fundamental mechanisms of mutualistic relationships between autotrophs and satellite heterotrophs as ROS scavengers will help the development of cultivation techniques to isolate novel lineages of microbes, which is one of the ultimate goals of microbial ecology.

 

To understand the relationship between cyanotoxin and hydrogen peroxide productions in nature, hydrogen peroxide concentrations were quantified in the surface water of Florida lakes along with the measurement of cyanotoxin production (i.e., microcystin). By using a novel hydrogen peroxide microsensor, the high resolution measurements (a millimeter level) were made in the surface lake and river waters. This approach led the discovery of thin surface hydrogen peroxide maxima that have been overlooked in past research because they cannot be detected using standard surface water sampling techniques.

 

Detoxification of hydrogen peroxide is a critical component of the establishment of microbial mutualisms. The growth patterns of enrichment cultures and axenic autotrophic cultures and their satellite heterotrophs were studied to determine their mutualisms through ROS dynamics. Our analysis showed that axenic cultures were more sensitive to ROS stress than the unialgal cultures, which are formed by a single species of cyanobacterium but contain a few satellite bacteria. We reevaluated interactions between microorganisms, cultivation media, and ROS to improve the cultivation of previously unculturable microorganisms. Our idea was that the information garnered through this project would allow for the cultivation of previously unculturable microorganisms.  We were able to improve our cultivation skills and successfully isolated new chemolithotrophic microorganisms through this project.  Their genome sequences were determined and the data are available in public, and some cultures were deposited into public microbial culture collections.

 

This EAGER project involved multiple undergraduate and graduate student participation; female and minority students were involved.  These students gained valuable experience working on this project. The students worked closely with the PIs, learning and conducting chemical analysis and molecular microbiology techniques for their senior research and thesis projects. These students also gained valuable experience by attending PI and laboratory meetings to learn how tasks are defined and assigned. All participants attended, network, and presented their work to the scientific and layperson community. Dissemination and sharing of research results was accomplished through the timely preparation of peer-reviewed publications, local TV news and website contents. The data were also presented in three conferences held in Florida. These low cost intrastate meetings gave us unmatched opportunities to provide new information to our algal bloom monitoring partners such as Florida Department of Environmental Protection, Florida Department of Health, Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC), and County governments. Cyanotoxins present a significant threat to human health globally and efforts are underway to combat their impacts. These activities require thoughtful translation of scientific and technical jargon to accurately convey the purpose and importance of the project to the general public (cyanobacteria blooms are a big issue in south Florida). The students and PIs both benefitted from these experiences.

 

As an extension project, we actually used hydrogen peroxide to treat naturally occurred cyanobacterial blooms. Our cyanobacterial bloom control experiments using accurate hydrogen peroxide concentration measurements benefitted the use of Caloosahatchee River water use (recreational and drinking) and provided valuable data to new Florida water management policies for future use of hydrogen peroxide as a chemical control of harmful algal blooms.
